review_detail: You won't stick with Miss Hokusai because you absolutely must know what happens next. Sometimes it's worth sticking with something just to be immersed.

Miss Hokusai gets jarred by a few too-modern music-moments and some preciousness in Ōi and Onao's sisterhood, but otherwise it's a steady sail through one woman's artscape and life that can't be entirely her own.
Told through the eyes of Hokusai's daughter as she attempts to forge a destiny of her own out of her father's shadow, Miss Hokusai is animation for adults that packs an emotional punch.

While the emphasis on suggestion over standard biopic spectacle is novel, one suspects the film probably won't be suggestive, coherent or affecting enough for hardcore Hokusai admirers, leaving it to occupy a curious artistic no-man's-land.
A film with an appealing sensibility that invites the public into a dream world where eroticism, sarcasm, comedy, and nostalgia dwell in every scene. [Full review in Spanish]

The art here is rawer and more idiosyncratic than some other anime, and there is a pleasing matter-of-factness about fleshy matters - drinking, sex, sickness - even as the more abstract question of art's practice and power is under consideration.
Visually gorgeous but doesn't adequately capture a compelling figure.

... the film's strongly centralized human nub holds a simple and lucid power, weaving enough deeply felt, fundamental goodness and compassionate integrity to conquer even its wildest and most undisciplined ideas.
Animation isn't the usual style associated with biopics, though there have been some sterling examples... To those can now be added Miss Hokusai.

The animation is superb, with fine attention to period detail, and director Keiichi Hara's use of modern music - some of it rock-infused - is apt accompaniment to a story of a young woman who lives life boldly by refusing to bend to cultural norms.
This plush anime version of Hinako Sugiura's original manga tells a tale in a poetic, episodic fashion.
A visually rich look at the often messy act of creation.
Japanese animation meets its own origins in Miss Hokusai, a lovingly crafted tale of art and life in early-18th-century Japan.
"Miss Hokusai" can be an abrupt picture, but it retains sizable charisma and artistry, locating a few emotional moments that work exceptionally well.
Although it's lovely to look at, the movie is disjointed and is told through a seemingly random collection of vignettes, some of which are more memorable than others.
A sumptuous tapestry of color, shadow, and light.
If you adjust to the movie's unusual rhythms and submit to director Hara (whose credits include the similarly singular Colourful), you'll find yourself having a lovely, quietly soulful experience.
Historical Japanese character study has mature content.

Miss Hokusai bleeds style and grace from every frame to the extent that you can almost smell the ink as it's pressed to a paper canvas. For the imaginative and the admirers of the fantastical, this film is purely and spectacularly a work of art.
The spell "Miss Hokusai" casts is a powerful one that lingers long after the lights go up in the theater.
It condenses everyday interactions, memories, and dreams into a potent mix of all the major ingredients of a well-lived life.
Miss Hokusai is a thoughtful and visually resplendent anime with a playful interpretation of art and artists.

Miss Hokusai can sometimes feel a little too light on its feet, with a tendency to meander from the narrative path, but its dipping in and out of various lives and dramas, makes it all the more vibrant and unique.

With Hinako Sugiura's historical manga 'Sarusuberi' as his inspiration, director Keiichi Hara and screenwriter Miho Maruo have pared down the episodic source material to create a work that is truly magical: must-see storytelling at its finest.
More impressionistic and contemplative than dramatic and analytical, this is an intriguing memoir of a significant female artist.
Miss Hokusai is a high-profile Japanese anime that is completely (and refreshingly) devoid of fantastical creatures, floating castles and sharpshooting cyborgs.
The beautiful animation is a strong selling point: it's detailed and realistic, with some frames deliberately echoing well-known prints by Hokusai.
This historical biography is a quiet examination of a father and daughter/master and apprentice as they ply their copious talents to create works of art for their patrons.
An important and mature film about 19th century Japanese artist Hokusai and his brilliant, perhaps equally talented daughter.

There are meditations on mortality, art, relationships, love, fear, sexuality and spirituality in this sumptuous-looking film. They cohere into a portrait of a young woman as complex as any big screen character can be.
Set in the 1800s during the final years of the Edo period, the film reimagines that era with dozens of lovely details.
We watch the visions of her imagination, from dragons in the sky, on down, transformed into art.
Director Keiichi Hara achieves a balance between earthiness and aestheticism, suggesting a Japan on the cusp of modernity.
It feels much longer than its 90 minutes, and I left it feeling like I didn't really learn much about its title character or her father.
Hara's use of exaggerated sound compensating for O'Nao's lack of sight [is] even more compelling than his visuals...easily one of the best animations of the year
A slim, brief affair ... but the brevity may well be part of the reason the film stays with us.
While it's not entirely kid-friendly, this portrait of an artist is both enchanting and thought provoking.
Creating worlds with images is a form of magic. Miss Hokusai demonstrates that simply, with its extraordinary simulation of sunlight streaming through O'Ei's spread fingers.
It is just an exquisitely lovely, emotionally mature film that is deeply satisfying precisely because of the sadness in its soul.
[An] unusual, visually adventurous animated feature, simultaneously modern and steeped in Japanese culture and history.
A gorgeous animated tale of love, family and art set during Japan's Edo period.
Miss Hokusai is a lovely biopic, even if it never quite picks up and focuses on a single thread. (Then again, neither does life.)
Magical and melancholy, tender and robust.
The "roaming hands" dream is one of Miss Hokusai's most memorable set pieces, but it's far from the only standout.
That an anime film can explore such complex subjects so beautifully in what's nominally an artist's biopic is a blessing in itself.

It is an interesting work, delicately and discreetly animated, with a quiet visual coup in its final moments when the Edo (as it was then called) of 1814 is dreamily replaced by the Tokyo of the 21st century.
The annals of Western art are woefully sparse when it comes to female painters, which is just one of perhaps a dozen reasons that Miss Hokusai comes as such a refreshing anomaly among anime exports.
